titleInfo.title: Library at Booker T. Washington High School

originInfo.publisher: Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library and Information Center

location.physicalLocation: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University

mods.abstract: This photograph of the library at Booker T. Washington High School shows African American students quietly reading and a librarian standing under a poster reading "Silence."
mods.accessCondition: Courtesy of the Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library and Information Center

Reproduction permitted for non-profit educational and research purposes only. All reproductions require acknowledgement of the contributing institution. For research inquiries about specific objects, contact the Memphis and Shelby County Room, Memphis Public Library and Information Center.

relatedItem.abstract: Tennessee’s history between the end of the American Civil War (1865) and the end of World War II (1945) often gets ignored. Citizenship—what that has meant and how that has changed—is at the heart of this digital exploration into Tennessee history and culture “between the wars." The stories you can explore through the objects, songs, photographs, paintings, and documents of this website are often those of challenges and obstacles placed before those who pursued the rights and benefits of citizenship.

mods.note: Digital Initiatives, James E. Walker Library, Middle Tennessee State University
